q: What are the main symptoms of norovirus?
a: The main symptoms of norovirus are feeling sick (nausea), diarrhea, and being sick (vomiting).

q: How can norovirus be treated at home?
a: The best way to treat norovirus at home is to rest and have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration. Symptoms usually improve in 2 to 3 days.

q: How is norovirus spread?
a: Norovirus can spread through close contact with an infected person, touching surfaces or objects with the virus, or consuming food prepared or handled by someone with norovirus. Washing hands with soap and water is the best prevention method.

q: When should I seek urgent advice for norovirus?
a: You should seek urgent advice from 111 if you are worried about a baby under 12 months, your child stops breastfeeding or bottle feeding, a child under 5 years shows signs of dehydration, you or your child still have signs of dehydration after using oral rehydration sachets, you or your child cannot keep fluids down, or you or your child have bloody diarrhea or vomiting for an extended period.

q: How can I get help for norovirus?
a: You can get help by contacting 111 for advice, visiting a GP, or going to A&E if the symptoms are severe such as vomiting blood, green vomit (in adults), swallowing something poisonous, having a stiff neck and sensitivity to bright light, or experiencing a sudden, severe headache or stomach ache.

q: What should I do if I have severe pain from norovirus?
a: If you have severe pain from norovirus that makes it hard to think or talk, prohibits sleep, or difficult to perform daily activities, you should seek immediate medical attention.

q: Can hand sanitizers kill norovirus?
a: No, hand sanitizers or alcohol hand gels do not kill norovirus. Washing hands with soap and water is the best way to stop its spread.

q: How long does norovirus typically last?
a: Norovirus usually goes away in about 2 days, with symptoms starting suddenly within 1 to 2 days of being infected.

q: Should I stay off school or work if I have norovirus?
a: Yes, it is recommended to stay off school or work until you have not been sick or had diarrhea for at least 2 days. This is when you are most infectious.

q: What should I do if I suspect norovirus?
a: If you suspect norovirus, you should rest, stay hydrated, and follow proper hygiene practices such as frequent handwashing. If symptoms worsen or persist, seek medical advice.

q: What are the main symptoms of norovirus?
a: The main symptoms of norovirus are feeling sick (nausea), diarrhea, and vomiting. Other symptoms may include a high temperature, headache, and aching arms and legs. The symptoms start suddenly within 1 to 2 days of being infected.

q: How can norovirus be spread?
a: Norovirus can spread very easily. It can be caught through close contact with someone who has the virus, touching surfaces or objects that have the virus on them and then touching your mouth, or eating food that has been prepared or handled by someone with norovirus. Washing your hands frequently with soap and water is the best way to stop it from spreading.

q: What should I do if I think I have norovirus?
a: If you think you have norovirus, it is important to rest and have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration. You can usually treat yourself at home and will usually start to feel better in 2 to 3 days. However, if you are worried about a baby under 12 months, if your child stops breast or bottle feeding while they're ill, or if you or your child have signs of dehydration or other severe symptoms, it is important to seek urgent medical advice from 111 or go to A&E if necessary.

q: How long should I stay off school or work if I have norovirus?
a: You should stay off school or work until you have not been sick or had diarrhea for at least 2 days. This is when you are most infectious. It is also important to not visit hospitals or care homes during this time.

q: How can I treat diarrhea and vomiting in children and adults?
a: To treat diarrhea and vomiting in children and adults, it is important to rest and have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration. You can also consider using oral rehydration sachets. If symptoms persist or if you have signs of dehydration or other severe symptoms, it is important to seek medical advice.

q: What should I do if I'm worried about a baby under 12 months with norovirus?
a: If you're worried about a baby under 12 months with norovirus, it is important to seek urgent medical advice from 111. They can provide guidance and arrange a phone call from a nurse or doctor if needed.

q: When should I call 999 or go to A&E if I have norovirus?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if you vomit blood or have vomit that looks like ground coffee, have green vomit (adults) or yellow-green/green vomit (children), suspect you have swallowed something poisonous, have a stiff neck and pain when looking at bright lights, or experience a sudden, severe headache or stomach ache. If you are unsure about the severity of your symptoms, it is best to seek medical advice.

q: What should I do if I have severe pain due to norovirus?
a: If you have severe pain due to norovirus, it is important to seek medical attention. You can call 111 to get advice or go to A&E if necessary. Severe pain is described as pain that is always there and so bad that it's hard to think or talk. If you have moderate or mild pain, you may still seek medical advice if it is affecting your daily activities or causing discomfort.

q: What are the main symptoms of norovirus?
a: The main symptoms of norovirus are feeling sick (nausea), diarrhea, and being sick (vomiting).

q: How can norovirus spread?
a: Norovirus can spread through close contact with someone infected, touching surfaces or objects with the virus, and eating food prepared by someone with norovirus.

q: What should I do if I suspect norovirus?
a: If you suspect norovirus, the most important thing is to rest and have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration. Stay off school or work until you have not been sick or had diarrhea for at least 2 days.

q: When should I seek urgent advice for norovirus?
a: You should seek urgent advice from 111 if you're worried about a baby under 12 months, your child stops feeding while they're ill, a child under 5 years has signs of dehydration, or if you or your child have bloody diarrhea or vomiting for an extended period.

q: What should I do in case of severe symptoms?
a: If you or your child vomit blood, have swallowing something poisonous, have a stiff neck and pain when looking at bright lights, or have a sudden, severe headache or stomach ache, call 999 or go to the nearest A&E.

q: Can alcohol hand gels kill norovirus?
a: No, alcohol hand gels do not kill norovirus. Washing your hands frequently with soap and water is the best way to stop it from spreading.

q: How long does norovirus usually last?
a: Norovirus usually goes away in about 2 to 3 days. It's important to rest and have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration.

q: What should I do if I suspect dehydration?
a: If you suspect dehydration, especially in children, seek medical advice. If you or your child still have signs of dehydration after using oral rehydration sachets, it's important to get medical attention.

q: Can a GP help with norovirus?
a: A GP may be able to help you with norovirus. You can ask for an urgent appointment or check with the GP surgery before going in as they may speak to you on the phone.

q: What are the different levels of pain associated with norovirus?
a: Severe pain is always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk. Moderate pain always there, makes it hard to concentrate or sleep. Mild pain comes and goes, and is annoying but doesn't stop you from doing daily activities.
